For tree species, upward and poleward shifts have been observed, but with some inconsistencies. Upward shifts of trees, primarily in response to temperature change, have been observed in a wide range of studies (
4 ,
21 ), but downward shifts have also been observed as a result of tracking moisture (
22 ). Poleward shifts of tree species have also been observed worldwide but with some exceptions (
7 ,
15 ). For example, Woodall et al. (
23 ) found that in the eastern United States, the mean latitude of seedlings shifted greater than 20 km north for the northern species, whereas southern species did not move; Zhu et al. (
24 ) found no indication of tree range expansion.
